text: Paternal expression of <extra_id_0> WT1 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> in human fibroblasts and lymphocytes .

The Wilms ' tumor suppressor gene ( <extra_id_0> WT1 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> ) was previously identified as being imprinted , with frequent maternal expression in human placentae and fetal brains .
We examined the allele-specific expression of <extra_id_0> WT1 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> in cultured human fibroblasts from 15 individuals .

Seven of 15 fibroblast lines were heterozygous for polymorphic alleles , and the expression patterns were variable , i.e . , equal , unequal or monoallelic paternal expression in three , two and two cases , respectively .
Exclusive paternal expression of <extra_id_0> WT1 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> was also shown in non-cultured peripheral lymphocytes from the latter two individuals .

The allele-specific expression profiles of other imprinted genes , <extra_id_0> IGF2 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> and <extra_id_0> H19 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> , on human chromosome 11 were constant and consistent with those in other tissues .

text: Our unexpected observations of paternal or biallelic expression of <extra_id_0> WT1 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> in fibroblasts and lymphocytes , together with the previous findings of maternal or biallelic expression in placentae and brains , suggest that the allele-specific regulatory system of <extra_id_0> WT1 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> is unique and may be controlled by a putative tissue - and individual - specific modifier .
